Hm. It is hard to tell you why, but.. maybe the population size is 
too sma=
ll? If the population size is too small and there are many 
species, there =
is not enough room for mating, I mean the mating pool 
is too small and the=
 space is not searched very efficiently.

wrote:

values 
> in a specific problem. I noticed tha=
t in different experiments 
there 
> are different parameter values, but I =
don't know why, though they 
are

omething that tells you the

.

ould not get a satisfied answer, and I thought the output I need

milar to DPM. Could you tell me why? I had not expected that you

eply so fast, morning.

> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski"=
 
> <petar_chervenski@> wrote:
> >
> > Well basically you need to understan=
d how two genotypes (NNs) are 
> > compared so that it is determined whethe=
r they are in the same 
> > species or not. 
> > The total number of excess=
 and disjoint genes is counted, as well 
> as 
> > the average weight diffe=
rence of matching genes. These 3 values 
are 
> > then multiplied by their =
importance factors and summed up to 
> produce 
> > the distance value. If =
that distance value is less than the 
> > compatibility threshold, then the=
 genotypes are in the same 
> species, 
> > else they are in two separate s=
pecies.
> > So what you need to adjust is the importance factors and the 
>=
 > compatibility threshold. 
> > There is no general rule on how to adjust =
the importance factors, 
> but 
> > notice that if you set them all to 1.0,=
 this basically means that 
a 
> > weight difference of 1.0 is as important=
 as one excess or one 
> > disjoint gene. (I assume that the numbers of exc=
ess/disjoint 
genes 
> > are absolute, they are not divided by genome size)=
. 
> > You can also make the compatibility treshold dynamic, that is, 
> ch=
oose 
> > a target number of species and alter the compatibility threshold =

> each 
> > generation, if there are too many species, raise it, or lower =
it 
if 
> > there are too few.
>
